H0.text: The balloon has a positive charge and the comb is neutral, which is the most likely reason the comb is able to repel the balloon after the students rub the balloon against his hair, rub the comb through her hair, place the comb near the balloon, and observe the repulsion.

H1.text: The balloon and the comb have the same electrical charge, which causes the comb to repel the balloon when they are placed near each other after each has been rubbed against hair.

H2.text: The balloon has a negative charge and the comb is neutral, which explains why the comb repels the balloon after the students rub the balloon against their hair several times and pass the comb through hair several times and then place the comb near the balloon.

H3.text: The balloon and the comb have opposite electrical charges, which is why the comb repels the balloon after both are rubbed against hair several times.

A4.text: Video demonstrating tribocharging with a plastic comb rubbed by a cotton cloth attracting small pieces of paper.

A5.text: Video of a charged rod demonstration at the University of Minnesota showing repulsion after rods are tribocharged, different cases giving repulsive and attractive forces.
